awd_titl_txt: Travel: ISCRE 27: Chemical Reaction Engineering for Sustainable Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The most important events for the international reaction engineering scientific community have historically been the International Symposia on Chemical Reaction Engineering. The 27th International Symposium on Chemical Reaction Engineering (ISCRE 27) was organized to take place June 11-14, 2023, in Québec City, Canada. This symposium provides a focus on the frontiers of chemical reaction engineering related to sustainability, with an opportunity for international networking within the scientific community. ISCRE meetings are held biennially, rotating between North America, Europe, and Asia. This international reputation combined with the efforts of the organizing and scientific committees ensures a vibrant and diverse mix of participants, which offers supported students and researchers the opportunity to engage and learn about the practical technology challenges facing companies that apply chemical reaction engineering expertise. The conference organizers anticipated approximately 330 in-person attendees from academia, industry, and government based on previous ISCRE conferences held in North America. Funding requested from the National Science Foundation will be utilized to support the travel of early-career faculty, post-doctoral researchers, and graduate students, with an emphasis on participation of underrepresented groups.

The ISCRE 27 technical program is focused on the challenges of sustainable development and how chemical reaction engineers can address these challenges through their work. The Scientific Committee comprises sixty leading academic and industrial researchers in sustainable chemical engineering from around the world. Technical Sessions cover emerging sustainable engineering focus areas such as CO2 Capture & Utilization, Electrocatalysis & Photocatalysis, Electrification of Chemicals Manufacturing, Waste Upcycling, Hydrogen Production and Storage, and Biomass Conversion. A combination of more than 150 oral presentations and 150 poster presentations were planned to give students and early career researchers a forum for sharing their work and expertise. Technical Workshops will offer students the ability to learn additional practical skills such as Laboratory Reaction Engineer (taught by Dow experts), Technical Writing, and Reactor Scale-up Techniques. The awarded NSF funds will subsidize expenses such as registration, travel, and hotel accommodations for students, postdocs, and researchers. The nominee’s CV and presentation abstract along with any recommendation letters from research advisors were evaluated by the ISCRE 27 Scientific Committee as the merit for the travel awards. The diverse makeup of the conference attendees also presents the awardees the possibility for international technical exchanges and cooperation. Supported attendees will be able to submit their research for publication in special issues of Chemical Engineering Journal and Chemical Engineering Science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 27th International Symposium on Chemical Reaction Engineering (ISCRE) held on June 11-14, 2023 in Quebec City, Canada, was successful, in large part, because it included the participation of U.S.-based junior scientists and engineers.  Their travel and participation in the conference, the primary goal of this award, were made possible by funding from the National Science Foundation.  The ISCRE meetings, which occur every three years, are the crown jewel events of the world-wide chemical reaction engineering community. Secondary goals of sponsoring participation through these travel awards included,

  • Timely and creative exchange of research and development results and ideas about the application of chemical reaction engineering to the solution of important technological problems facing society.
  • Enhanced industry-university interactions.
  • Exposure of graduate students and young researchers to frontier research problems and researchers.
  • Strong international cooperation through foreign participation.
  • Exposure of the public to the important impact of chemical reaction engineering on the solution of major technological problems, such as the utilization of waste and biomass as a source for transportation fuels and chemicals.

The ISCRE 27 technical program focused on the challenges of sustainable development and how chemical reaction engineers can address these challenges through their work.  The Meeting's Scientific Committee comprised sixty leading academic and industrial researchers in sustainable chemical engineering from around the world. Technical Sessions covered emerging sustainable engineering focus areas such as CO2 Capture & Utilization, Electrocatalysis & Photocatalysis, Electrification of Chemicals Manufacturing, Waste Upcycling, Hydrogen Production and Storage, and Biomass Conversion, among others.

Twenty-one junior scientists and engineers from U.S. academic institutions were sponsored and presented their research at the Meeting.  In total, 344 registered participants attended the meeting with 172 from Northern America, 128 from Europe, 38 from Asia Pacific, 5 from the Middle East, and 2 from South America.  Of those, 75 were from the U.S., 95 from Canada, 12 from India, 12 from South Korea, 5 from Japan, and 5 from China.  Participants based on sector were 85% Academia, 14% Industry, and 1% Government (38% graduate students and postdoctoral trainees).  A combination of 181 oral presentations and 120 poster presentations gave students and early career researchers a forum for sharing their work and expertise and building.  Technical Workshops provided students the ability to learn additional practical skills such as Laboratory Reaction Engineer (taught by Industry experts), Technical Writing, and Reactor Scale-up Techniques.  The diverse makeup of the conference attendees also presented the awardees the possibility for international technical exchanges and cooperation.  Residual funds from the award were used to make 7 additional travel awards for junior scientists and engineers to attend the ISCRE 28 Meeting on June 16-19, 2024 in Turku/Abo, Finland.  The ISCRE 28 program focused on transformative reaction engineering, and the conference received similar attendance.  Special issues for each of the two conferences were created by Chemical Engineering Journal, which ultimately led to the dissemination of the researcher's work world-wide through 64 peer-reviewed publications.  The professional development of the travel award recipients, and the improvement in public knowledge of the relevant topics and the associated research have been accomplished.
